moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 e6 3. Nc3 Nc6 4. Nb5: White puts pressure on the c7 pawn.  Black's only defense will leave his d file pawns doubled.
moves.4... Bd6 5. Nxd6+ cxd6 6. e3 h5 7. Nf3 f: White could castle--the knight is protecting the queen.  But black's move makes the queen trade look imminent.
moves.13. Qxa5 Nxa5 14. O-O-O: Black will advance the bishop to protect the pawn.
moves.14... Be6 15. Nd2 Bf5 16. Bd3 Be6 17. e4: ?  This move leaves white's a2 pawn vulnerable to the black bishop.  White will be able to trap the bishop behind enemy lines, however.
?  I don't see white's strategy behind sacrificing the b pawn.  The a pawn is well defended.
moves.26... Nxb4 27. Ra4 Nbd5 28. Rha1: ?  White is throwing away his black bishop?  For a pawn?
moves.28... Nxe3 29. g4 a5: Black declines the en passant to protect the a pawn.
moves.30. Ra4a3 Nc4+: Black forces a knight exchange by forking white's rook.
moves.31. Nxc4 Nc8: :)  Black realizes that RxN leaves him vulnerable to Bd5+, pinning the rook.  Not even an exchange, just a free rook.  Nc8 looks like a retreat.  Although it protects the b pawn, it doesn't really help the knight get in the game.
